author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italy’s Prime Minister Visits Trump at Mar-a-Lago
description: Giorgia Meloni, the Italian prime minister, joins just a handful of other world leaders who have been to the president-elect’s Florida estate since his victory.
content: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy visited President-elect Donald J. Trump on Saturday at his Florida golf club for an informal meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Costas Simitis, 2-Time Prime Minister of Greece, Dies at 88
description: Mr. Simitis imposed financial measures to prepare for Greece’s entry into the eurozone and laid the groundwork for the Olympic Games’ return to Athens.
content: Costas Simitis, a former prime minister of Greece who oversaw his country’s entry into the euro single currency and its uneven preparations for the 2004 Olympic Games, died on Sunday. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Scammers Could Cheat New York’s New Congestion Pricing Tolls
description: Drivers who obscure their plates or otherwise circumvent paying tolls already cost the city’s mass transit system millions of dollars.
content: Each year, scofflaw drivers in New York City cheat their way out of paying tolls, costing the region’s mass transit system millions in lost revenue. And already, some drivers are thinking about ways to avoid the new congestion pricing tolls that will apply to those who enter the busiest part of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 5, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 5, 2025.
content: An article this weekend on page 3 about the history and impact of an American Dance Festival program to train dancers in China misidentified a person Yang Meiqi helped train. It was the dancer Duan Ni, who founded TAO Dance Theater with the choreographer Tao Ye, not Tao Ye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Why New York’s Congestion Pricing Tolls Started at Midnight Sunday
description: The program was eased into place in the middle of a weekend night in case of unexpected kinks.
content: Starting just after midnight on Sunday, drivers began paying a new fee to enter the heart of Manhattan. The toll is part of New York City’s plan to reduce some of the world’s heaviest traffic while raising billions of dollars to pay for improvements to mass transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: This Might Just Be the Best Way to Eat Kale
description: Kale sauce pasta, a recipe I adapted from the chef Joshua McFadden, is still one of my most favorite things to cook.
content: If you were ever put off by particularly old, fibrous kale leaves in a salad — the eternal chewing, the unpleasant dank green flavor — it’s hard to imagine that boiling the leaves and blitzing them with fried garlic, olive oil and Parmesan completely transforms them into a silky, luxurious sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rose
title: Can BAM Be a Trailblazer Again Through A.I.?
description: The Brooklyn organization, seeking new audiences and pushing boundaries, debuts Techne, four digital installations from the Onassis Foundation’s ONX Studio.
content: “A journalist finds himself in the woods.” Marc Da Costa, a digital artist with a Ph.D. in anthropology, was speaking from the controls of an artificial intelligence-driven video installation at the Onassis Foundation’s ONX Studio, a high-tech media lab in the Olympic Tower in Midtown Manhattan. He was talking to the computer that runs this installation. About me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Recovered From a Fall
description: Rena Cohen’s crossword is best solved in pencil.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Laura Boushnak
title: In Damascus, Syrians Reclaim Freedoms Off Limits Under al-Assad
description: Residents of Syria’s capital are picnicking on a once-forbidden mountaintop and trading openly in dollars and imported Nescafe. They say the city seems theirs again.
content: For much of her life, Sumaya Ainaya spent weekend and summer nights on Mount Qasioun, which overlooks the city of Damascus, joined by other Syrians drinking coffee, smoking hookah and eating corn on the cob roasted on grills nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Richard Foreman, Iconoclastic Playwright and Impresario, Dies at 87
description: The Ontological-Hysteric Theater, which he founded in 1968, presented more than 50 of his plays, among them “My Head Was a Sledgehammer” and “Permanent Brain Damage.”
content: Richard Foreman, the relentlessly teasing, deliberately mysterious avant-garde playwright and impresario who founded the Ontological-Hysteric Theater, won a bookshelf full of Obie Awards and received a MacArthur fellowship in his late 50s, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Boyagoda
title: An Overdose Sends a Widower Hunting for His Wife’s Lost Descendants
description: The new novel by Bernhard Schlink, the author of “The Reader,” explores the legacies of World War II and reunification in contemporary Germany.
content: When it comes to women revealing what they really think about their families after they die, it’s hard to top Faulkner’s Addie Bundren, reflecting from beyond the grave on the grudges and loathing she lived with as the unwilling matriarch of a dysfunctional Mississippi brood. A century later in Germany, the dead woman at the center of Bernhard Schlink’s new novel, “The Granddaughter,” gives Addie a run for her money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Driver in Ramming Attack Made Trips to New Orleans and Abroad
description: Shamsud-Din Jabbar visited New Orleans twice, and traveled to Egypt and Canada, before a burst of violence early on New Year’s Day that killed 14 people.
content: Months before the man behind the New Orleans terror attack plowed a truck into a New Year’s Day crowd, he rode through the area on a bicycle, recording videos of his target using eyeglasses with a built-in camera, investigators said on Sunday. He was back again a few weeks later, they said, probably to continue his plotting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen DuVal
title: Enough With the Land Acknowledgments
description: Instead of proclaiming performative acknowledgments of Native peoples, institutions should establish strong relationships with Native nations.
content: If you work at a university, large corporation or left-leaning nonprofit or have attended certain performances, you have probably heard a land acknowledgment, a ritual that asks you to remember that Native Americans were here long before the peoples of Europe, Africa and Asia. The New York City Commission on Human Rights, for example, on its website “acknowledges the land politically designated as New York City to be the homeland of the Lenape (Lenapehoking) who were violently displaced as a result of European settler colonialism over the course of 400 years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Berry Wang
title: Hong Kong’s Cabbies, Long Scorned and Frustrated, Face the End of an Era
description: A government push to modernize taxi services comes up against the habits of drivers known for driving fast and accepting only cash.
content: The air is laced with cigarette smoke and Cantonese profanities as half a dozen taxi drivers hang out by their fire-engine-red cabs on a quiet corner of the gritty Prince Edward neighborhood of Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I’ve Been to All the Popular Tourist Sites at Least Once’
description: Taking pictures of standpipes, a dancer on the subway in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,297
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Jan. 6, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Sees the U.S. as a ‘Disaster.’ The Numbers Tell a Different Story.
description: President Biden is bequeathing his successor a nation that by many measures is in good shape, even if voters remain unconvinced.
content: To hear President-elect Donald J. Trump tell it, he is about to take over a nation ravaged by crisis, a desolate hellscape of crime, chaos and economic hardship. “Our Country is a disaster, a laughing stock all over the World!” he declared on social media last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Launches New Attack in Kursk Region of Western Russia
description: Ukrainian forces’ assault was in the Russian region where they made a surprise incursion last summer.
content: Ukrainian forces have gone on the offensive in the Kursk region of Russia, Ukrainian and Russian officials said Sunday, in what appeared to be an effort to regain the initiative there as they struggle to thwart relentless Russian assaults across eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Jes Aznar
title: On the Run, a Hit Man Gives One Last Confession
description: Edgar Matobato says he killed again and again for former President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines. Now he’s trying to stay alive to testify.
content: There are, the hit man said, many ways to kill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: A Frigid First: Chile’s President Visits South Pole to Bolster Antarctic Claims
description: Gabriel Boric’s trip to the pole, which his office called the first by a Latin American president, comes amid rising competition for influence in Antarctica.
content: Chile’s president visited the South Pole on Friday in a bid to fortify his country’s territorial claims to part of Antarctica, as competition in the region is growing bit by bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Jeju Air’s Problems Mount After Crash That Killed 179 People
description: South Korea’s leading low-cost carrier, heavy with debt and its stock already near record lows, is now facing intense public and government scrutiny.
content: When Jeju Air’s status as South Korea’s biggest low-cost carrier seemed under threat from the merger of the country’s two biggest airlines last year, the company’s chief executive assured employees that it would “actively respond,” possibly by acquiring smaller rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Grabar
title: The Future of the Democratic Party Is Rolling Down Broadway
description: A model for how to deliver for voters without getting stuck in a traffic jam — political or otherwise.
content: One of the lesser-known acts of the French Revolution, in the days before the storming of the Bastille, was a series of attacks on the toll barriers at the boundaries of Paris. These customs houses were a natural target for angry commoners: They levied the octroi, a tax on goods entering the city that was both an everyday financial burden and a symbol of oppression. When the revolutionary government formally abolished the tolls a couple of years later, Parisians celebrated on the Champs-Élysées. (One product that had just lost its heavy tax was wine.) By that time, the king and queen were under house arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John R. Bolton
title: John Bolton: Presidents Expect Loyalty. Trump Demands Fealty.
description: Neither kings nor presidents nor their countries are well served if they are surrounded by sycophants and rent seekers.
content: Four years ago this Monday, Donald Trump pressured Mike Pence to pursue a surreal interpretation of the vice president’s constitutional role in counting the Electoral College votes. Mr. Pence refused, igniting Mr. Trump’s fury for not subordinating either philosophical or constitutional principles in service to him, thereby showing “disloyalty.” Thus ended Mr. Pence’s usefulness to Trumpworld, albeit honorably for Mr. Pence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Eating Healthy
description: The science behind Well’s ultraprocessed foods challenge.
content: I love those sprinkle-covered sheet cakes you can buy at the supermarket — so much so that when my daughter was small, I trained her to grab the corner piece for me at birthday parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Austria Coalition Talks Collapse, Raising Prospects for the Far Right
description: The leader of the anti-immigrant Freedom Party of Austria, founded by former Nazis in the 1950s, was expected to be asked to enter into talks to form a new government.
content: The far-right Freedom Party of Austria gained a realistic chance this weekend of leading the country’s next government, after talks between three mainstream parties collapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Olympic Sprinter Charged in Confrontation With Miami Beach Police
description: A lawyer for Fred Kerley, a two-time Olympic medalist, described the police handling of the situation as “an unreasonable use of force.”
content: Fred Kerley, a two-time Olympic medalist sprinter for the United States and one of the fastest runners in the world, was arrested late Thursday night in Miami Beach, Fla., after an altercation with the police in South Beach, a gathering place for tourists that is known for its nightlife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aquilino Gonell
title: For Many of Us, Jan. 6 Never Ended
description: Donald Trump is promising to pardon Jan. 6 rioters. But we can’t let him rewrite history.
content: For those who didn’t experience the violence, Jan. 6, 2021, might feel like it’s in the past — but it’s not for me. I keep reliving the five horrific hours of that cold Wednesday afternoon, as I tried to protect elected officials, regardless of their political ideology, and their staffs inside the Capitol building — all without firing my gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Golden Globes Photos: See All the Looks From the Red Carpet
description: Stars made their glittering arrival for the 82nd Golden Globes, an awards season opener of sorts that celebrates the biggest stars in film and television.
content: By some measures, awards season dressing has already been underway for weeks: Festival juries and critics associations hand out trophies, and if stars deign to collect them in person, propriety generally demands that they be clothed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: As Democrats Reel, Two Front-Runners Emerge in a Leadership Battle
description: The race to lead the Democratic National Committee centers on the favorites, Ken Martin and Ben Wikler, but the party’s infighting over them looks nothing like a broad reckoning with its 2024 defeats.
content: Days before Republicans take full control of Washington, the Democratic National Committee is mired in an intramural fight that is less about how the party found itself locked out of power than about disputes over donor influence, personality conflicts and past slights and jealousies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Gas Cutoff Sends Shivers Through a Russian-Backed Breakaway Region
description: A renegade part of Moldova once boasted it would become a Russian-speaking Switzerland. Now without gas, its leader assured residents, “We will not allow a societal collapse.”
content: The shop used to sell flowers and gardening gear to visitors from just down the road, where a tiny breakaway region of Moldova has for more than 30 years stood defiantly apart, with support from Russian troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Israel Conducts Raids in Syria Amid Accusations of Cease-Fire Violations
description: Four weeks after the fall of the Assad regime, Israel is pressing on with a military campaign on Syrian soil.
content: The Israeli military said on Sunday that it has been conducting “operational raids” in recent weeks on Mount Hermon in Syria, continuing a military campaign on Syrian soil that is drawing increasing international condemnation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Jimmy Carter’s Heart Was in Plains. But His Launchpad Was in Atlanta.
description: While his home was always in the small Georgia town, Atlanta gave him the opportunities to cement a political and humanitarian legacy.
content: The mythology of Jimmy Carter begins and ends in Plains, the small Georgia town that raised him and kept drawing him back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: The Hero of This Novel Is 14. His Married Girlfriend Is 36.
description: Adam Ross’s “Playworld” is about a child actor and the real-world dramas that engulf his adolescence.
content: Before “adulting,” there were grown-ups: a word even more squiggly, if you think about it, and one that in Adam Ross’s new novel, “Playworld,” takes on monstrous dimensions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Digging in the Desert to Comfort Families of the Missing
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 5, 2025.
content: “Dignity and human rights do not end with death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry and Alan Feuer
title: ‘A Day of Love’: How Trump Inverted the Violent History of Jan. 6
description: The president-elect and his allies have spent four years reinventing the Capitol attack — spreading conspiracy theories and weaving a tale of martyrdom to their ultimate political gain.
content: In two weeks, Donald J. Trump is to emerge from an arched portal of the United States Capitol to once again take the presidential oath of office. As the Inauguration Day ritual conveying the peaceful transfer of power unfolds, he will stand where the worst of the mayhem of Jan. 6, 2021, took place, largely in his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Isabelle Taft and Emily Kask
title: The Uneasy Relationship Between New Orleans and Its Most Famous Street
description: Bourbon Street is the lifeblood of the New Orleans tourist industry. But after an attack that killed 14, along with other recent violence, some people who work and live there wish for change.
content: A woman from out of town spilled from a bar onto Bourbon Street double-fisting a pair of fluorescent alcoholic drinks known as hand grenades. Not far away, a reveler wearing only a thong and a black cowboy hat straddled a column outside of a club. And another few blocks over, Joseph Holmes, 25, tap-danced on the sidewalk for tips, just like he had since he was 5 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Ana Ley
title: New York City Welcomes Congestion Pricing With Fanfare and Complaints
description: The program had defied many obstacles over the course of decades. It debuted over the weekend on what seemed to be a successful first day.
content: Congestion pricing arrived in New York City exactly one second after midnight on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Students Charged in ‘To Catch a Predator’ TikTok Scheme
description: Five students at Assumption University in Worcester, Mass., are accused of luring a man to campus, where he was chased by a group of about 25 people.
content: Five college students in Massachusetts are accused of luring a man to the Assumption University campus in a plot that the police said was inspired by the television show “To Catch a Predator” and a fad on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: The First Day of Panama’s Canal
description: Recalling the day in 1999 when former President Jimmy Carter completed a historic handoff.
content: The journalist David Gonzalez was at the Miraflores locks in Panama on Dec. 14, 1999, to record this milestone for the front page of The New York Times:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 575
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Jan. 6, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: What Do Movie Producers Do, Anyway?
description: And why do they get the trophy for best picture at the Oscars?
content: Do you have a question for our culture writers and editors? Ask us here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: Potent Storm Blasts Parts of U.S. With Sleet, Snow and Freezing Rain
description: All highways in northeastern Kansas were closed on Sunday evening, bringing traffic to a standstill in some places.
content: A fierce storm barreling across the country toward the Mid-Atlantic States pounded a vast area with a wintry mix of sleet, snow and freezing rain that the Weather Prediction Center warned could bring “significant disruptions” to daily life and travel on Sunday and Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: N.Y. Judge’s Ruling Shows How Legal Issues Will Follow Trump Into Office
description: Donald Trump may not face a penalty for his conviction in the hush-money case, but he could still be the first felon to be president — and civil proceedings against him continue.
content: As President-elect Donald J. Trump prepares for his inauguration, some of the legal cases that spilled out of Mr. Trump’s first presidency will follow him into the second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Theroux
title: The Hard Reality American Expats Quickly Learn
description: Expatriation was nonetheless the making of me: liberated me, humbled me, revealed to me who I was and what I wanted my life to be.
content: Does this annoying American rant sound familiar?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Hailing a Car in Midtown Manhattan is Becoming More Expensive
description: Transportation officials want to reduce the number of taxis, Ubers and Lyfts that idle in heavy traffic. To do that, they will charge riders new fees.
content: Many of the vehicles that crowd the tolling zone are taxis and cars for ride-hailing services such as Uber and Lyft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: How Trump Re-Wrote Jan. 6
description: Plus, the end of an era for Hong Kong’s cabbies
content: Four years ago today, protesters stormed the Capitol with clubs, chemical irritants and other weapons, inflamed by Donald Trump’s lie that the election had been stolen from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Military Pounds Gaza as Pressure Mounts for Cease-fire
description: Gaza’s health ministry said that 88 people had been killed over the past day. Israeli and Hamas officials have been holding indirect cease-fire talks via mediators in Qatar.
content: Dozens of Israeli strikes pounded the Gaza Strip over the weekend as Israeli and Hamas officials continued indirect cease-fire talks through mediators in Qatar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Demi Moore, Nicole Kidman and Colman Domingo Party Before the Golden Globes
description: Celebrities packed into a suite at the Chateau Marmont in Los Angeles for the W Magazine party on Saturday night.
content: In the movie “The Substance,” Demi Moore plays an entertainer in her 50s so intent on hanging onto stardom that she signs up to take a potion that will restore her youth, but at a horrific price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli
title: Bad Bunny Talks Coming Back Home on His ‘Most Puerto Rican’ Album Yet
description: In an exclusive video interview, the world-conquering Latin superstar discusses why his new album is filled with traditional sounds and rhythms from his homeland.
content: Over the last few years, Bad Bunny — the global superstar of reggaeton and Latin trap whose astonishing success has remade the pop landscape for Spanish-language music — gained the world. Three chart-topping Billboard albums. A headlining slot at Coachella. The title of most-streamed artist on the planet. A burgeoning acting (and wrestling) career. A creeping interest in his romantic extracurriculars by the paparazzi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Former Nurse Is Charged After Newborn Is Found With Fractures
description: Erin Strotman was charged in one case of child abuse, but detectives were also examining other episodes with similar injuries at a Virginia neonatal intensive care unit.
content: A Virginia woman was charged with child abuse on Thursday over her connection to mysterious injuries that appeared on a newborn in a neonatal intensive care unit in a hospital where she worked as a nurse, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Telemedicine for Seniors Gets a Last-Minute Reprieve
description: Some older Americans have come to depend on virtual consultations with doctors, covered by Medicare. To keep that option in the future, Congress will have to act quickly.
content: Since his cancer diagnosis last year, Kent Manuel has regularly seen an oncologist near his home in Indianapolis. It’s been a tough time: After spinal surgery for paralysis caused by his cancer, he is regaining the use of his legs with physical therapy but still uses a wheelchair.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should TV Ads for Drugs Be Banned?
description: Readers discuss a proposal by some Trump allies. Also: The abuses inside prisons; stories of miracles.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: California Police Department Agrees to Reforms After Federal Inquiry
description: The Antioch Police Department was under investigation by the Justice Department after racist text messages between its officers were released in 2023.
content: The police department in the Northern California city of Antioch has agreed to be monitored by federal officials for five years after reports of racist and sexist texts by officers drew outrage and led to a civil rights investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In About-Face, Musk Trashes Farage, U.K.’s Anti-Immigrant Populist
description: Elon Musk, the billionaire backer of Donald J. Trump, had been promoting Nigel Farage. But on Sunday Mr. Musk said Mr. Farage “doesn’t have what it takes.”
content: It was an abrupt turnabout, even for the easy-come, easy-go nature of alliances in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s political orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
title: Who Should the Academy Nominate in 2025?
description: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.
content: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bad Bunny on His ‘Most Puerto Rican’ Album Yet
description: In an exclusive interview, the world-conquering Latin superstar discusses why his new album is filled with traditional sounds and rhythms from his homeland.
content: In an exclusive interview, the world-conquering Latin superstar discusses why his new album is filled with traditional sounds and rhythms from his homeland.
source.name: The New York Times
